Steven Taschuk wrote:
> Quoth Bill de h�ra:
>   [...]
> 
>>One think I don't like about the way Junit does test suites, aside 
>>from the effort of remembering to add a test to a suite, is that it 
>>drives the dependencies downward. AllTests at the top of the tree 
>>has to know about all the tests or testsuites below it.
>>[...] This seems to introduce cycles in Java packages [...]
> 
> 
> Is there a problem with having such cycles?

Glad you asked. Normally I'd say yes - you don't want cycles in an 
object graph. In this case I'm not so sure it's a problem, because 
it might just be my own private definition of what clean code looks 
like and Java seems more forgiving than C++ wrt cycles. And I'm 
pretty sure Gamma and Beck and the legion of developers that use and 
extend JUnit know about dependency cycles. All of which are why I'm 
after opinions - I don't get what's special about JUnit that would 
absolve it of this matter.

The solution for me was to stop using suites, invent a marker 
interface and have a treewalker load classes that met the interface, 
but that's inefficient. Another option is to follow a naming 
convention and collate the tests that way - this does stop you 
loading up classes twice, but has the disadvantage of being a 
convention as opposed to being something actually enforceable in the 
language (imo it's not much better than an ide depending on magic 
comments).

Bob Martin has a section in his new book on this subject, which is 
why I've thinking about it again. Cycles are to be avoided, and one 
answer he proposes is to apply a dependency inversion to the code. 
In Junit I think you could make this happen in Junit by allowing 
TestCases to be visted by TestSuites. That would keep the 
dependencies unidirectional with the bonus of not having constantly 
go to back the suite and add the test cases to it, which seems to be 
the main reason people write a test collecting treewalker - this way 
you'd just add the suite to the test instead which is where you 
happen to be in the code.
